natural problem: Suppose that I have an unlimited supply of identical math books, history books, and physics books.  All are the same size, and I have room on a shelf for 8 books.  In how many ways can I arrange eight books on the shelf if no two books of the same type can be adjacent?
natural solution: We can choose any book for the first position on the shelf. This is $3$ possibilities. After placing this book, we can choose either of the other two types of books to place directly after it.
Similarly, there will be two choices for the third book once the second has been chosen. There will be two choices for each book after the first.
So, the total number of ways to arrange the books on the shelf will be: $$3\times2\times2\times2\times2\times2\times2\times2=3\cdot2^7=\boxed{384}.$$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes math_books history_books physics_books shelf_space :: nat
assumes h0 : "shelf_space = 8"
and h1 : "math_books + history_books + physics_books = shelf_space"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i < shelf_space \<longrightarrow> 
  (math_books ! (i - 1) \<noteq> math_books ! i) \<and>
  (history_books ! (i - 1) \<noteq> history_books ! i) \<and>
  (physics_books ! (i - 1) \<noteq> physics_books ! i)"
shows  "card {P. permutations P = math_books + history_books + physics_books} = 384"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that I have an unlimited supply of identical math books, history books, and physics books.  All are the same size, and I have room on a shelf for 8 books.  In how many ways can I arrange eight books on the shelf if no two books of the same type can be adjacent? The final Answer is 384
 ### Proof
 We can choose any book for the first position on the shelf. This is $3$ possibilities. After placing this book, we can choose either of the other two types of books to place directly after it.
 Similarly, there will be two choices for the third book once the second has been chosen. There will be two choices for each book after the first.
 So, the total number of ways to arrange the books on the shelf will be: $$3\times2\times2\times2\times2\times2\times2\times2=3\cdot2^7=\boxed{384}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes math_books history_books physics_books shelf_space :: nat
assumes h0 : "shelf_space = 8"
and h1 : "math_books + history_books + physics_books = shelf_space"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i < shelf_space \<longrightarrow> 
  (math_books ! (i - 1) \<noteq> math_books ! i) \<and>
  (history_books ! (i - 1) \<noteq> history_books ! i) \<and>
  (physics_books ! (i - 1) \<noteq> physics_books ! i)"
shows  "card {P. permutations P = math_books + history_books + physics_books} = 384"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There is a shelf with space for 8 books. The shelf will hold math books, history books, and physics books such that the total number of books is equal to the shelf space. No two consecutive books can be of the same type (math, history, or physics). How many different ways can the books be arranged on the shelf? The final answer is 384.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes math_books history_books physics_books shelf_space :: nat
assumes h0 : "shelf_space = 8"
and h1 : "math_books + history_books + physics_books = shelf_space"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1..7}. math_books!i \<noteq> math_books! (i+1) \<and> history_books!i \<noteq> history_books! (i+1) \<and> physics_books!i \<noteq> physics_books! (i+1)"
shows  "card {p. p permutes {1..8} \<and> (\<forall>i \<in> {1..7}. p i \<noteq> p (i+1))} = 384"
